ratings.question_text: Your level of engagement with the course was:
What is your overall assessment of this course?
The course was well organized to facilitate student learning.
I received clear feedback that improved my learning.
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the level of intellectual challenge of this course was:
Relative to other courses you have taken at Yale, the workload of this course was:

narratives.question_text: What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
comments: Learned a lot about microwave engineering from a practical standpoint, as well as how to address issues theoretically. Gave me a much better grasp of how to incorporate microwave engineering concepts into my labwork.
Learnt a lot about microwave engineering, particularly practical examples that seem very useful in my field of research.
Design and working performance of various microwave components used in my field of research

narratives.question_text: What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
comments: Rob knows the topic better than anyone - has a lot of personal insight to offer on top of the standard material. The project is a great way to learn the content, and more useful than a final/midterm. More homework might have helped cement some of the course concepts a bit earlier in the course.
More than one assignment might have helped us understand the course better
More problem sets might help. The teaching style of the instructor was definitely a strength

narratives.question_text: Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
comments: Yes. You will learn as much about microwave engineering as you need to do research in the field, and yet it still v accessible.
Absolutely, if microwave engineering is required in your line of work.
